Dear Rick

You ask for evidence that the 'lost wax' method of casting was k=
nown to 
the Japanese and you are, of course, quite correct in your asserti=
on 
that the typical Namban tsuba could only have been cast by using this 
=
tecnique.  Evidence exists in Japan of the extensive use of both 
the 'clos=
ed form' and the 'lost form' methods of casting - the former 
being known i=
n China as early as the Zhou dynasty (1122-249 BC) and the 
latter being in=
troduced there 'relatively late'. 

Many Japanese artefacts could only have=
 been produced by the use of 
this tecnique, and kagami are but one example=
 of this. The detail of 
many cast objects, especially in bronze, could not=
 have been acheived 
any other way.

Thus my belif in the casting of Namban=
 tsuba presumes the use of 
a 'lost form' method.  The naked-eye evidence o=
f casting; the knowledge 
that this form as casting was widely known in Jap=
an; and the acceptance 
that no other contemporanerous method of casting co=
uld have produced 
these artefacts seem to support this presumption. 

I wo=
uld be interested to hear your further comments.

Regards, John L.
